reviews.title: Not Bad but expensive

reviews.text: Stayed here 5/24 & 25, Sat. & Sun. Not too bad but very expensive in the‘ season, $120 - $130 – After Memorial day. Basic motel room – no coffee maker, breakfast, refrig, or microwave. Just a TV & phone. If you stay in a room near the office may get Wi-Fi, otherwise, only in the lobby. We were in room 224, near the office and had a weak but useable signal. Within walking distance to everything in the town. And the town is just outside the entrance to TR National Park. Unless you want to stay in a not too distant town, it’s about the most reasonable, relatively speaking, thing available.

reviews.title: The place to stay in Medora
reviews.text: My family found Medora to be an odd little town. Most historic towns that I have visited have at least a few old houses, etc. As far as I could tell, Medora exists almost entirely for tourism, and a large majority of the tourist accommodations (motels, restaurants, shows, campgrounds) are run by a single entitty. True it was an historic town with a long history, but it appears to have been totally, completely reinvented without any of the old time residents around. Many of the folks who work there are summer employees (college students, senior volunteers, young folks from abroad), rather than town residents. It was so odd I looked it up in the Census, and Medora truly only has 51 households and about 100 total residents. I guess that's what explains the lack of grocery stores or other non-touristy stores. The Badlands Motel is the largest accommodation in town (and owned by the same organization), and it almost seems like the motel theme park for the town of Medora.

This lack of residents was a little disconcerting, but it also makes for a lovely vacation. From the Badlands Motel, situated right next to the Badlands themselves, you can walk the entire 3 or 4 blocks of town at virtually any time of the night. As previous reviewers said, there are no fastfood, no starbucks, no national chains (aside from a rogue AmericINN), also virtually no way to buy food to self-cater aside from driving to the next town. It is a refreshing change from almost every other small town in the USA, to not see McDonalds and DQ.. We went to the pizza joint, and ate breakfast at one of the 3 coffee shops (both owned by the nonprofit). The restaurants were not cheap, but not outreageous either. There is a wonderful playground right behind the motel (seems like the motel's playground?), that is a replica of an old west town.
reviews.title: A little gem in the North Dakota Badlands

reviews.text: Our stay at the Badlands Motel was better than expected, especially after we read some of the reviews from other travelers. First of all, Medora is a very small town (pop. 95), so nobody should be expecting the Ritz. This is a summer tourist town that stands alone.
reviews.title: Serves your needs for a clean place to lodge and sleep

reviews.text: The motel is old - my wife and her sister remember staying here with their family 50 years ago. However, the rooms are clean, the beds comfortable, and the wrap around showers are classic. The pool was a popular spot. It has a deep end depth of 9 feet, clearly left over from the days when diving boards were around .
reviews.title: one of the few places to stay

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The airc onditioners for each room are running 24/7 in the summer, but that does help keep the rooms insulated from outside noise. The veteran travelers knew to bring lawn chairs, so you could sit outside, take in the views, and have a cold beverage or two while visiting with friends and family. There is an individual cup of coffee maker in the room ( but no refrigerator), and the office had free coffee and ice available.No restaurant, but everyone wants to walk around the town and eat at the local spots anyways. The whole town is only about 8 blocks, so walking the streets is part of the charm of the destination. This hotel provides you all that you need, with a little character thrown in.

reviews.text: your choices are pretty limited. this is a standard mom and pop type hotel room, not a hampton inn.... It was clean enough, my bed was very comfy (but i had my doubts when i got into the room) Train whistles are a bit annoying but anyplace in town will have that problem as the town is in an "alcove" of the surrounding country and the train runs along the base of that ridge. didn't really enjoy medora overall and had no problem leaving a day early. The folks at the motel were very nice, easy going. the only reason i would tell someone to stay there is that there are just not many places to stay, and you can walk to the restaurants etc. from here, and the TR NP enterance is only a few blocks down the street. It was clean, serviceable. but that's about it. very short on charm!
reviews.title: Overpriced and terrible beds!

reviews.text: Arriving without reservations left us at the mercy of the few accommodations that were open in post season. However there was no effort made to take advantage here as in the other hotel we contacted. The room was servicable and very clean. The bed was small and not particularly comfty, and the bathroom fan mentioned by another reviewer was a distraction. However, the price was fair for the services provided and while not luxurious, certainly met the needs of travelers wanting to enjoy the park. Anyone bothered by the trains passing through town should think about spending the night somewhere else and not pass judgement on their whistles as being a problem for the hotel to deal with.

reviews.text: We stayed one night at the Badlands Motel over Labor Day weekend. The motel is very clean and has a outdoor pool and miniture golf. But as the above review said it is close to the railrood tracks. They first gave us a room right by the crossing so I asked to be moved and they moved us a about 10 doors down so it helped but not much. We did the Medora Musical and that was wonderful. I highly recommend that but the Pitch Fork Fondue was only so so. Biggest problem is after the fondue there is an hour and a half wait before the musical starts - hard with little kids. My husband golfed the new course and loved it. Some of the best views he had ever seen on a golf course.

reviews.title: Old But Great!
reviews.text: I stayed at the Badlands Motel in August, 2002, with my two children (ages 7 and 11). We were on our way from Yellowstone to Mpls. It was a good experience; they have a nice outdoor pool and a wonderful miniature golf course. The kids LOVED the place. The motel room was old but well kept. It had cable TV, and plenty of hot water for all of us. The motel stands at the base of the Badlands, which provides an impressive backdrop. The entire town of Medora was extremely friendly and made us feel comfortable even though we were just passing through. The only negatives I encountered were as follows: 1) They placed us in a room at the motel that was away from the center area so we had more privacy & less traffic - BUT we were right next to some train tracks. And there seemed to be about 1 train per hour that screamed through there, blasting its whistle. I slept very poorly, due to that, & if I'd been planning on staying more than one night I would've insisted on a different room (closer to the pool & the office, and away from the train tracks).2) It's a little bit tough to find a place to eat after 8 pm on a weeknight. There are no fast food places in Medora, which is OK, I just wish I'd realized it ahead of time. All in all, however, it was a great experience and I would definately recommend the Badlands Motel to anyone looking for a friendly, comfortable place to stay in this attractive area of ND.
